facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 142 of 1956 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 142 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1954, of the Labour Appellate

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 13, 1954 of Labour Appellate Tribunal of India Calcutta Bench in Appeal No. Cal-87 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1954, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India  Calcutta Bench  in Appeal No. Cal-87 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 5, 1957 by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. November 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with special leave arises out of an application made by the appellant to the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , seeking permission to discharge the respondents from its employ.

facts.text: Appellant made application to Industrial Tribunal, Bihar under s.33 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 seeking permission to discharge respondents from employ.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with special leave arises out of an application made by the appellant to the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , seeking permission to discharge the respondents from its employ.

facts.text: Respondents were in employ of appellant and staying in two storeyed house in Patna rented by appellant for housing workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were in the employ of the appellant and were staying in a two storeyed house in the city of Patna which had been rented by the appellant for housing its workmen.

facts.text: Occurrence took place on November 20, 1952 in the house wherein respondents were involved.

anchor.surface_text: On November 20, 1952, an occurrence took place in the said house wherein the respondents were involved.

facts.text: Written reports of the occurrence sent on November 21, 1952 to appellant's Chief Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: Written reports of the said occurrence were sent on November 21, 1952, to the appellants Chief Engineer and the respondents were placed under suspension the same day.

facts.text: Respondents placed under suspension on November 21, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Written reports of the said occurrence were sent on November 21, 1952, to the appellants Chief Engineer and the respondents were placed under suspension the same day.

facts.text: Industrial dispute pending between appellant and its workmen before Industrial Tribunal, Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: An industrial dispute was then pending between the parties i.e., the appellant and its workmen before the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar,

facts.text: Original application filed by appellant on November 21, 1952 under s.33 for permission to dismiss respondents for misconduct under cl.17 b viii of Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: original application which had been filed by the appellant on November 21, 1952, for permission to dismiss the respondents from its employ as per el. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders.

facts.text: Respondents made application under s.33A on November 27, 1952 alleging breach of s.33 by suspension.

anchor.surface_text: On November 27, 1952, the respondents also made an application before the said Tribunal under s. 33A of the Act inter alia on the ground that their suspension by the appellant as aforesaid was a breach of s. 33 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant made application on December 6, 1952 to seek permission to discharge under cl.14 a instead of dismissal under cl.17 b viii.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1952, the appellant made an application before the said Tribunal stating that on a reconsideration of the facts of the case of the respondents the original prayer for permission to dismiss the the respondents was number being pressed,

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal made award on May 14, 1953 dismissing respondents' s.33A application and granting permission to discharge with one month's pay in lieu of notice within 15 days.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, entertained the same and after hearing the parties duly made its award on May 14, 1953, dismissing the respondents application under s. 33A of the Act and granting the appellant permission to discharge the respondents from its employ with effect from the date of the order on payment to the respondents of one months pay in lieu of numberice within 15 days therefrom.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal against IT order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents carried an appeal against the said order of the Industrial Tribunal granting the appellants application under s. 33 of the Act before the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside IT order finding no misconduct under cl.17 b viii and no jurisdiction to grant relief as notice given.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal thereafter companysidered whether the appel- lant had made out a case under cl. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders and came to the companyclusion that the respondents had number been guilty of any misconduct within the meaning of that clause and that therefore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal granting permission to the appellant to terminate the services of the respondents was liable to be set aside.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal found appellant's application dated December 6, 1952 bona fide and discharge simpliciter under cl.14 a, not punitive.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, expressly recorded the finding that the application for leave to discharge the respondents from its employ was bona fide and what the appellant did by making the application dated December 6, 1952, was actuated by an honest motive of exercising its right to discharge the respondents under el. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of visiting upon the respondents the penalty of dismissing them from its employ under el. 17 b  viii  thereof.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no appeal lay to Labour Appellate Tribunal as no substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: Once the Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that the application dated December 6, 1952, and the discharge of the respondents for which . the permission of the Industrial Tribunal was sought were in the honest exercise of the appellants rights, numberquestion of law, much less a substantial question of law companyld arise in the appeal filed by the respondents against the decision of the Industrial Tribunal and the Labour Appellate Tribunal was clearly in error when it entertained the appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside LAT decision and restored Industrial Tribunal order of May 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal and restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953.

facts.text: Retrenchment defined by Ordinance in October 1953 followed by Act 43 of 1953 published December 23, 1953.

issues.text: Whether an appeal lay from the order of the Industrial Tribunal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: no appeal from the order of the Industrial Tribunal lay to the Labour Appellate Tribunal under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950. He contended that the said order was not a decision within the meaning of that expression in s. 7 and even assuming that it was so, the appeal neither involved any substantial question of law nor was it a decision in respect of any of the matters specified in sub- s.  1  b  of that section.

issues.text: Whether the order of the Industrial Tribunal under s.33 was a 'decision' within the meaning of s.7 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: He contended that the said order was not a decision within the meaning of that expression in s. 7 and even assuming that it was so, the appeal neither involved any substantial question of law nor was it a decision in respect of any of the matters specified in sub- s.  1  b  of that section.

issues.text: Whether any substantial question of law was involved in the appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken on behalf of the appellant before the Labour Appellate Tribunal that no substantial question of law was involved and as such the appeal was not maintainable. The Labour Appellate Tribunal was of the opinion that the appellant had alleged misconduct against the respondents and could not be allowed to adopt the expedient of terminating their services by giving notice for the requisite period or payment of salary in lieu of notice and that the Industrial Tribunal, therefore, ought not to have entertained the application for amendment of the prayer of the original application in which the appellant wanted to dismiss the respondents for misconduct.

issues.text: Whether the appellant could amend its application under s.33 from seeking dismissal under cl.17(b)(viii) to discharge under cl.14(a) of the Standing Orders without holding an enquiry.
Whether the appellant's application dated December 6, 1952 for permission to discharge under cl.14(a) was bona fide and a discharge simpliciter without unfair labour practice or victimization.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, expressly recorded the finding that the application for leave to discharge the respondents from its employ was bona fide and what the appellant did by making the application dated December 6, 1952, was actuated by an honest motive of exercising its right to discharge the respondents under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of visiting upon the respondents the penalty of dismissing them from its employ under cl. 17 b  viii  thereof.

issues.text: Whether the discharge of the respondents amounted to retrenchment under s.2(oo) of the Act, making the appeal maintainable under s.7(1)(b) of the IDAT Act.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the definition of the term retrenchment to be found in s. 2 oo  of the Act the discharge of the respondents by the appellant really amounted to retrenchment and retrenchment being one of the matters specified in sub-s.  1  b  of s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, the respondents had a right of appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

arguments.claim: Appellant alleged misconduct and could not adopt expedient of terminating services by notice or pay in lieu; IT ought not to have entertained amendment of prayer.

arguments.claim: Respondents not guilty of misconduct under cl.17(b)(viii); IT order granting permission liable to be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal thereafter companysidered whether the appel- lant had made out a case under cl. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders and came to the companyclusion that the respondents had number been guilty of any misconduct within the meaning of that clause and that therefore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal granting permission to the appellant to terminate the services of the respondents was liable to be set aside.

arguments.claim: No appeal lay from IT order to LAT under s.7 IDAT Act; order not a 'decision'; no substantial question of law; not in respect of matters in sub-s.(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: Shri H. N. He companytended that the said order was number a decision within the meaning of that expression in s. 7 and even assuming that it was so, the appeal neither involved any substantial question of law number was it a decision in respect of any of the matters specified in sub- s.  1  b  of that section.

arguments.claim: Appellant's action was punitive discharge under cl.17(b)(viii) due to alleged misconduct, not cl.14(a); cannot terminate without charge-sheet and enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The answer of Shri P. K. Chatterjee on behalf of the respondents was that the action of the appellant in the matter of the termination of the services of the respondents was punitive in character, that the discharge of the respondents for which permission was sought by the appellant was a punitive discharge, that such discharge was by reason of the alleged misconduct of the respondents falling within cl. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders and number within cl. 14 a  thereof and that the substantial question of law which arose in the appeal was whether the appellant companyld be allowed to adopt the expedient of terminating the services of the respondents, without going through the procedure of submitting a charge- sheet to the respondents and holding a proper enquiry in the matter of those charges, by merely giving numberice for the requisite period or payment of salary in lieu of numberice and thus resorting to el. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of cl. 17 b  viii  of the same.

arguments.claim: Discharge amounted to retrenchment under s.2(oo); appealable under s.7(1)(b) IDAT Act.

anchor.surface_text: The other answer made by Shri P. K. Chatterjee was that having regard to the definition of the term retrenchment to be found in s. 2 oo  of the Act the discharge of the respondents by the appellant really amounted to retrenchment and retrenchment being one of the matters specified in sub-s.  1  b  of s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, the respondents had a right of appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

arguments.claim: Application dated Dec 6, 1952 was bona fide; honest motive to discharge under cl.14(a) instead of dismiss under cl.17(b)(viii); discharge simpliciter.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC upheld IT finding; no QOL arises from honest exercise of rights.

arguments.claim: Once IT found bona fide discharge simpliciter, no question of law, much less substantial QOL, arose; LAT erred in entertaining appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Once the Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that the application dated December 6, 1952, and the discharge of the respondents for which . the permission of the Industrial Tribunal was sought were in the honest exercise of the appellants rights, numberquestion of law, much less a substantial question of law companyld arise in the appeal filed by the respondents against the decision of the Industrial Tribunal and the Labour Appellate Tribunal was clearly in error when it entertained the appeal.

arguments.claim: Discharge simpliciter not guilty of unfair labour practice or victimization if bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: The only question relevant to be companysidered by the Industrial Tribunal would be that in taking the step which it did the appellant was number guilty of any unfair labour practice or victimization. If the Industrial Tribunal did number companye to a companyclusion adverse to the appellant on these companynts, it would have numberjurisdiction to refuse, the permission asked for by the appellant.

arguments.claim: s.2(oo) definition of retrenchment not applicable as introduced after IT order (Ordinance Oct 1953, Act 43/1953 published Dec 23, 1953).

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the discharge of the respondents though patently it was a discharge simpliciter was, in substance, retrenchment within the meaning of the definition companytained in s. 2 oo  of the Act is equally untenable, for the simple reason that the term retrenchment was for the first time defined in the manner in which it has been done by an Ordinance promulgated in October 1953 which was followed by Act 43 of 1953 which was published in the Gazette of India on December 23, 1953.

arguments.claim: Suspension by appellant was a breach of s.33.

anchor.surface_text: On November 27, 1952, the respondents also made an application before the said Tribunal under s. 33A of the Act inter alia on the ground that their suspension by the appellant as aforesaid was a breach of s. 33 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: IT dismissed s.33A application; SC restored IT order.

arguments.claim: Application Dec 6, 1952 was amendment of original; IT should not entertain as evasion without enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: This application has been described by the Labour Appellate Tribunal as an application for amendment of the original application which had been filed by the appellant on November 21, 1952, for permission to dismiss the respondents from its employ as per el. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: do by its application of December 6, 1952, was, in effect, to substitute another application asking for permission to discharge the respondents from i

arguments.court_reasoning: SC held it was in substance a new bona fide application for discharge under cl.14(a).

arguments.claim: Appellant could substitute new application for discharge under cl.14(a), abandoning dismissal under cl.17(b)(viii).

anchor.surface_text: It must be numbered, however, that what the appellant purported to do by its application of December 6, 1952, was, in effect, to substitute another application asking for permission to discharge the respondents from its employ under el. 14 a  of the Standing Orders, thus abandoning the relief which it had prayed for in the original application.

arguments.claim: No proper enquiry held, but since no oblique motive, criticism invalid.

anchor.surface_text: If the appellant bad been actuated by any oblique motives and wanted to evade the companysequences of its number having held a proper enquiry, after submitting a charge-sheet to the respondents one companyld have understood the criticism made by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in regard to the same.

holdings.text: No appeal lay from the order of the Industrial Tribunal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950 as there was no substantial question of law involved.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Industrial Tribunal found bona fide discharge simpliciter under cl.14(a); no question of law arises from honest exercise of employer rights.

holdings.text: Once Industrial Tribunal found the application dated December 6, 1952 and discharge were in honest exercise of appellant's rights under cl.14(a), no question of law, much less substantial question of law, arose in the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Once the Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that the application dated December 6, 1952, and the discharge of the respondents for which . the permission of the Industrial Tribunal was sought were in the honest exercise of the appellants rights, no question of law, much less a substantial question of law could arise in the appeal filed by the respondents against the decision of the Industrial Tribunal and the Labour Appellate Tribunal was clearly in error when it entertained the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholding IT's finding of bona fides eliminates any legal issue for appeal.

holdings.text: The application dated December 6, 1952 was in substance a new application to discharge under cl.14(a), abandoning dismissal under cl.17(b)(viii), and Industrial Tribunal was competent to entertain it.

anchor.surface_text: It must be noted, however, that what the appellant purported to do by its application of December 6, 1952, was, in effect, to substitute another application asking for permission to discharge the respondents from its employ under el. 14 a  of the Standing Orders, thus abandoning the relief which it had prayed for in the original application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not mere amendment but substitution; IT found bona fide motive, no oblique intent to evade enquiry.

holdings.text: For permission under s.33 to discharge simpliciter, Industrial Tribunal need only consider if employer guilty of unfair labour practice or victimization; if not, must grant permission.

anchor.surface_text: The only question relevant to be considered by the Industrial Tribunal would be that in taking the step which it did the appellant was not guilty of any unfair labour practice or victimization. If the Industrial Tribunal did not come to a conclusion adverse to the appellant on these points, it would have no jurisdiction to refuse, the permission asked for by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discharge simpliciter under standing orders is employer's right if bona fide, limited check for unfairness.

holdings.text: Discharge simpliciter does not amount to retrenchment under s.2(oo) as the definition was introduced after the relevant events by Ordinance in October 1953 and Act 43 of 1953 published December 23, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the discharge of the respondents though patently it was a discharge simpliciter was, in substance, retrenchment within the meaning of the definition contained in s. 2 oo  of the Act is equally untenable, for the simple reason that the term retrenchment was for the first time defined in the manner in which it has been done by an Ordinance promulgated in October 1953 which was followed by Act 43 of 1953 which was published in the Gazette of India on December 23, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New definition not retrospective; IT order on May 14, 1953 predates it.

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to interfere with Industrial Tribunal's order granting permission under s.33.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of substantial question of law and non-applicability of retrenchment.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; Labour Appellate Tribunal decision set aside; Industrial Tribunal order of May 14, 1953 restored.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal and restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural outcome based on jurisdictional error of LAT.

justification_sets.label: Section 7 Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950 support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal and restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Labour Appellate Tribunal's decision set aside; Industrial Tribunal's order dated May 14, 1953 restored granting permission to discharge respondents.
directions: set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal
restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953

anchor.surface_text: Once the Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that the application dated December 6, 1952, and the discharge of the respondents for which . the permission of the Industrial Tribunal was sought were in the honest exercise of the appellants rights, no question of law, much less a substantial question of law could arise in the appeal filed by the respondents against the decision of the Industrial Tribunal and the Labour Appellate Tribunal was clearly in error when it entertained the appeal.
We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal and restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The only question relevant to be considered by the Industrial Tribunal would be that in taking the step which it did the appellant was not guilty of any unfair labour practice or victimization. If the Industrial Tribunal did not come to a conclusion adverse to the appellant on these points, it would have no jurisdiction to refuse, the permission asked for by the appellant.
We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal and restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the discharge of the respondents though patently it was a discharge simpliciter was, in substance, retrenchment within the meaning of the definition contained in s. 2 oo  of the Act is equally untenable, for the simple reason that the term retrenchment was for the first time defined in the manner in which it has been done by an Ordinance promulgated in October 1953 which was followed by Act 43 of 1953 which was published in the Gazette of India on December 23, 1953.
We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal and restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953.
